data.title: Gray brings love of the game to Samford
data.meta_description: Samford University football coach Bill Gray says athletes who play for \n him will have the best of two worlds - the atmosphere of a by-gone era \n when athletes played for their school and the love of…
data.text:
Samford University football coach Bill Gray says athletes who play for

him will have the best of two worlds - the atmosphere of a by-gone era

when athletes played for their school and the love of the game; and today’s

wide-open offenses and modern techniques.

Gray, interim head coach for the last five games last fall, is now

the head coach. And the future of Samford football appears to be in good

hands.

The coach spoke at the Kiwanis Club in our town Wednesday, courtesy

of Ronnie Watkins. The scene he painted of his school and its football

team is a lot like college football used to be.

"Small college athletics still belong to the kids," Gray said. "It’s

the purest form of athletics we have today. I hope they are in college

for the right reason - to get an education. They play ball more out of

a sense of pride for their school and because they want to play."

The kids don’t play before 80,-or-100,000 fans each week. But that’s

not important.

Money and pressure to win is not what sports programs should be about

on every campus. Gray played football for a small college, Mississippi

College; then was on the coaching staff there when it won a NCAA Division

II national championship.

He played in the old Gulf South Conference, when Jacksonville State,

Troy State, Livingston and Florence were also in that conference.

"That was a tough, competitive football conference - a sort of little

SEC," said Gray, explaining it broke up when some of the schools felt like

they should be playing at a higher level, but really should not have moved

up.

In 2003 Samford and Jacksonville State will become members of the Ohio

Valley Conference. It will be the first time Samford has been in a football

conference and able to compete for a championship.

Gray hopes nothing changes on campus, that no one gets too big-headed.

At Samford, the football coach can walk around campus same as a professor.

After a game he may be seen walking around in the stadium picking up things

or visiting with students and their families on campus.

Gray said the reason he does what he does is because at Samford he

is able to keep his priorities in order - faith, family and football.

"Right now my record as a head coach is 4-1," he said. "I don’t know

what my record will be when I’m through coaching. But I don’t want to be

remembered for my wins, but for what I taught the players about how to

live."

He has five children, ages 6 to 16, so he knows something about family.

He wants his team to be like a family; and his family like a team; with

everyone working together for a common cause.

His life was changed forever when he was named interim head coach on

Oct. 16 last fall. The Bulldogs were 1-4 and struggling.

He turned things around, going 4-1 in the next five games.

However, he refuses to take credit.

"Once a turtle wanted to go South for the winter, but it was too far

to walk. So he asked some Canadian geese to each grab a piece of rope as

they flew South. He bit down on the other end and was soon up in the sky,

hanging onto the rope for dear life.

"As the formation flew over, the country people began to notice the

geese carrying the turtle South. They said, ’Look at that. Whose brilliant

idea was that?’

"And the turtle, hearing their praise, opened his mouth and said, ’It

was I.’ You know what happened when he opened his mouth."

Gray isn’t like that.

He said there is a lot of good on the Samford campus and if athletes

happen to sign with the Bulldogs who don’t fit in, they don’t stay very

long.

All the players who don’t leave early, for whatever reason, graduate.

And few leave, since the graduation rate is around 90 percent, much higher

than the national average.

"Education has to be important to the athletes who come to Samford,"

he said. "I think this is the best of the two worlds."
